titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Employed part of the morning in writing to Mrs: Adams— Called again on Coll: Smith and pass’d a couple of hours with him— At half past three in the afternoon I embarked on board the Packet New-York, Captain Williams; we immediately sailed with a very fresh, and not unfavourable breeze— It was however too scant untill we came to the entrance of the Sound, at Sanders’s point, which we reached as the Sun was setting— After this we had a favourable wind for the remainder of the night; We came opposite the Huntingdon Light House 50 Miles from New-York, about 11. at Night— The passengers are few— Two Men; a married Lady, with three small children, and a young Lady from New-York going on a visit to Providence.

2. Though we had a prosperous breeze all Night, and little motion in the vessel, I could not sleep, and by four in the morning found my bed so irksome that I rose, we had then pass’d Faulkner’s Island, and continued with a very brisk and favourable breeze untill noon, when we reached point Judith— Here the wind almost instantaneously failed, and left us some time becalmed— Here also we found ourselves alongside of the Aurora another Packet, belonging to Newport, and which sailed after us yesterday— A breeze soon Sprung up, which was almost directly down the river, but which enabled us to beat up— About 4 in the afternoon we pass’d by Newport without stopping, and beat up the river untill near Midnight when we came to Anchor 8 or 9 Miles below Providence— In the Evening some of our Passengers, set the Cook to fiddle for them and amused themselves with dancing.

3. We had so nearly a dead calm that although we got under weigh by four this morning, it was close upon 10, when we landed at Providence— Here we found a Stage waiting for us; in which we immediately took Seats— Dined at Walpole, and arrived at Dedham between three and four in the afternoon. I had hopes of meeting my brother here, as the Court of Common Pleas have been in Session here this week. But he had been gone about 5 minutes when I arrived— I left the Stage here, and engaged Mr: Fuller to take me with a horse and Chair over to Quincy— I arrived at my father’s house, about 5 in the afternoon; only 49 hours from New-York, which is the shortest passage I ever made.— I found both my children here, and in perfect health— There was a company of Ladies with my Mother. My father and brother were not yet returned from Boston, but in the course of an hour or two came in.— My youngest child took me at first, for Mr: T. Greenleaf— But George recognized me immediately.

4. Heard a Mr: Willard, the youngest Son, of the late President of Harvard College— This afternoon I wrote to Mrs: Adams; pass’d the Evening at Mr: Cranch’s; and heard the proofs of George’s proficiency, which are very pleasing; but he has forgotten all his french— He reads very well for his age.

5. Part of the morning employed in writing— Went up to my own house, where I found almost every thing as we had left it— Return’d to my father’s to dinner— In the afternoon I attended the Town-meeting for the choice of a Representative— My brother, owing to some untoward circumstances which have occurr’d, declined a re-election— The candidates were Mr: Thos: Greenleaf, Jonathan Webb, and Captain Benjamin Beale, the last of whom was chosen at the third trial— At the two first Mr: Greenleaf stood the highest, Webb the next, and Beale the lowest— Webb’s voters finally threw their weight into the scale of Beale and decided the choice— On coming home we found Dr: Howard of Boston, and his Lady at my father’s. They however soon return’d to Boston.

6. I went with my father to Cambridge, and attended the inauguration of Mr: Samuel Webber as President of the College. At 11. in the morning, a procession was formed from the philosophy chamber to the meeting-house— The New President was inducted by the Lieutenant-Governor Robbins, in a latin Speech which he read indifferently, and by delivery of the Charter, the Book of Records, the Seal, and the Keys. The President then delivered a latin discourse; and an Oration in the same language was pronounced by a young Bachelor of Arts named Carey.— Two Anthems were performed, which with an introductory prayer by Dr: Lathrop, and a closing one by Dr: Elliot constituted the business of the day— The company afterwards all dined in the Hall— In the afternoon we called at Mr: Greenleaf’s, and at Mrs: Lincoln’s— I made some enquiries after accommodations for lodging, during the ensuing Summer, but without obtaining satisfactory information— We returned to Quincy, early in the afternoon.

7. I employed the greatest part of the day in writing; and commenced on a career towards which I look with concern and anxiety— In the Evening I went up to Mr: Cranch’s, to see my Son George. I found him well, and improving. It is a great cause of uneasiness to me to be compelled to separate myself from all my family so long, but it cannot be avoided.

8. Came in to Boston this morning with my brother, and took lodgings at Whitcomb’s; Concert Hall— We met on the Road Mr: and Mrs: Storer, with Mr: B. Hall of Medford— I transacted some business relating to my private concerns— Dined at Mr: Storer’s, and agreed with Mr: Hall to settle all the demands against my father on account of his Shares in the Middlesex Canal. Called this afternoon at Dr: Welsh’s; and spent part of the Evening at Mr: Parsons’s— Found him very unwell— He has this day been nominated chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the State; instead of Judge Dana, who has resigned.

9. I had appointed to meet Mr: B. Hall this morning, but on going out, met J. Hall, Mr: Gore, and several other Gentlemen, which detained me untill after the hour of appointment— It engaged my time the whole morning— Dined with Mr: T. C. Amory, with a company consisting chiefly of my old friends—D. Sargent—T. H. Perkins. J. Hall, and several others. Sir Isaac Coffin, an Admiral in the British service, and a kinsman of Mr: Amory’s was also there— He has just arrived from England, and is going to Canada— After dinner Messrs: James & S. G. Perkins, Gore, Otis, Callender, & W. Payne came in, and we sat at table untill almost 10 at Night.

10. Mr: B. Hall called upon me this morning, and I made the arrangement with him respecting the Assessments on my father’s Canal Shares— All the rest of the morning I was engaged in settling various private and personal affairs— Dined at Mr: G. Green’s—Governor Strong—Genl: Knox & his Lady—Mr: & Mrs: H. G. Otis—Lady Temple, her daughter and Granddaughter, Mr: & Mrs: J. Gore, and some others were there.— I spoke to Governor Strong, respecting the State Laws for the Library of
of Congress— Evening at home; writing to my wife, from whom I received a letter this Morning— I find I can apply very little time to writing here.

11. Heard Mr: Buckminster this morning, upon Christian humility— He is about to embark for England; on a voyage for his health— Between 1. and 2. Mr: Jos: Hall called upon me— We walked round the newly built part of the town, and upon the Common— Stop’d at Mr: J. Phillips’s— We dined at Mr: W. Payne’s— Mr: & Mrs: Gore, Sir Isaac Coffin, and Mr: & Mrs: Richards were there— After dinner Mr: James Perkins came in— He has just returned from England— I spent the Evening at home; and could only read, without much benefit.

12. I went to Cambridge this morning with Mr: Shaw, for the purpose of procuring lodgings for the ensuing Summer; after several ineffectual attempts I engaged two chambers in a house newly built by Mr: Porter, near the Inn, and engaged for board at his House, untill I could obtain further accommodation— I had much difficulty to secure this— We returned by the way of Charlestown— In the afternoon I went to look over Mr: Davenport’s House at Cambridge-Port— The same I visited last October; but cannot yet reconcile myself to it— Spent the Evening at Mr: S. A. Otis’s— His Son was there.

13. Busily, and properly employed all the morning— Dined with Mr: D. Sears, and a small company of Gentlemen. Among the rest Mr: J. Lowell who has just returned from a tour in Europe of two or three years— He was very communicative.— In the afternoon, I met Mr: Jos: Hall— Walk’d with him in the Mall— He was much engaged with the subject of the Election which is to come on to-morrow— In the Evening I attended a Caucus of federalists at Faneuil-Hall, who met to agree upon their list— Mr: H. G. Otis made them a very good speech— They agreed to chuse 27. Representatives, and adopted the names presented to them— Then a motion was made for five more, which after some opposition was adopted.— These names were also agreed upon, though preparation had not properly been made for this measure— I came home at about 10. They were then about to dissolve the Meeting— This was the first time I was ever present at a public Caucus— I once attended a private one, in 1793, or 1794.— It may be a necessary, but appears to me a clumsy way of transacting such business.

14. I went to Cambridge this morning to attend the sale at Auction of Mr: Pearson’s house and Land; but the sale was postponed, untill this day week. I went over the house and Lands; and enquired of Mr: Pearson the price which he would take for them; but he did not know— He was to consult his friend Mr: Phillips— I returned to Boston and dined with Mr: Gardner— In the Evening I attended the Wednesday Club, of which I have heretofore been a member. It was at Mr E. Gray’s; and was fully attended— I wrote but little this day.

15. My brother came in to Boston early this morning and invited me to go with him to Quincy which I accordingly did— Judge Cushing and his Lady dined with us at my father’s— In the afternoon I went to my own house and visited my garden— Called also at Mr: Cranch’s, where I found George, well— Evening in Conversation with my father.

16. Engaged all the morning, and great part of the Evening in writing.— This afternoon I went with my Mother to my own house and selected the part of the furniture which is to go to Cambridge to furnish the Chambers I have taken there. Took the children with us. Found part of my papers.

17. Finished this Morning the Introductory address. Looked over what I had written last Autumn as sketches for some of my first Lectures, and found them so uncouth and shapeless that I can hardly prevail upon myself now to use it— I employed the day however chiefly upon this business— In the afternoon I went to my own house; and selected some books and papers to send to Cambridge— I think however of making one more effort to procure furnished lodgings before I send the furniture. I found some trees coming up from the stones and seeds I set out last Summer, and Fall. Called at Mr: Cranch’s on my return, but he and Mrs: Cranch were both abroad— Evening in my writing chamber— My brother dined with the club at Mr: Millar’s— I transplanted yesterday and this day 35 peach-trees just from the stone from my brother’s treble tree to my Nursery at the Summer-house end of the Garden— Most of those which I transplanted last year from the Nectarine and other trees are yet alive— But my prospects of raising fruit-trees from the seed and Stone are weakened by my necessary removal from this place.— (George. 3. f. 6 2/10 I.) (John 2. f. 9. I .)

18. Heard Mr: Whitney this afternoon— Remainder of the day chiefly employed in writing to Mrs: Adams— Evening at Mr: Cranch’s— I took George there with me— Was engaged in looking over the papers, on the question made concerning the Estate where Mr: Cranch resides.

19. I intended to have gone into Boston this morning, but the Stage not going untill to-morrow, I had no convenient conveyance, and postponed my departure untill to-morrow— I spent the day almost in idleness; wrote nothing, and read very little— In the afternoon I went to my own house; unpacked one of the boxes of books which were put up the last Autumn, and took out some of the books which I wanted— I am very uneasy at the unsettled situation in which I still remain; and at the valuable time I am losing.— As I was returning home this evening I stop’d at Mr: Cranch’s door, and he gave me the papers respecting the Estate upon which he lives; the title to which is now to be tried in the Circuit Court of the United States.

20. I came into Boston this morning in the Stage. Called at Mr: Rogers’s, where I met Mr: Pearson— I found him unwilling to name a price for his house and land at Cambridge, from an apprehension, that it might affect the sale of it at the Auction to-morrow.— He appointed however 5 O’Clock in the afternoon to give me an Answer— I dined with Mr: S. A. Otis— After dinner, I met Mr: Pearson in the Street, and released him from his promise to fix upon a price previous to the sale at Auction— Evening at my lodgings: reading Boileau’s Translation of Longinus.

21. Mr: Rogers called on me this morning to go with him to Cambridge, and attend the sale of Mr: Pearson’s house, which I did— But there were no bidders, and it was struck off nominally at eight thousand dollars— It seems Mr: Pearson expected it would have sold much higher— After the sale he told me he was now determined to lease it— I gave up the chambers for which I had spoken at Porter’s, from the inconvenience it would be to furnish them, and I commenced a new search for others— Returned to Boston to dinner, and pass’d the Evening with the Club at Dr: Howard’s.

22. Called this Morning on Mr: Foster, and afterwards on Mr: Shaw respecting certain Certificates belonging to the Neponsit Bridge Corporation.— I found occasion to observe the loose manner in which the business of Corporations is apt to be done, and the necessity of continual superintendence over it— Remainder of the day, reading, and attending to the object which is now my chief occupation— Evening some what unwell.

23. Began writing sketches for lectures; employed all the morning at this business. My Mother was in town, and invited me to go to Quincy with her— But I feel the propriety of adhering to my business— I promised to go out to-morrow Evening. I spent the Evening at Mr: Parsons’s.— Application to me, to purchase my House in Half-Court-Square.

24. Mr: S. Welles called upon me this morning— I spent it in my chamber closely engaged in writing untill 1. I then saw Mr: Lowell respecting a couple of houses which he has for sale; and I had some conversation with him relative to the price he sets upon them— After dinner, I called at Dr: Welsh’s, and went out to Quincy in the Stage.— Received a letter from my wife— The proposition for the purchase of my house comes from a Mr: Fletcher, a broker, in behalf of a Company, of which Andrew Dexter is a member— We have agreed upon the terms and I am waiting only for the security which they have to offer— In this respect, my first duty must be caution.

25. Heard a young Gentleman named Hulbert— Wrote to Mrs: Adams; and could find very little time to write any thing else. In the Evening I went for half an hour to Mr: Cranch’s— Mr: Smith’s two Sons Isaac and Thomas are here to spend the week ensuing.

26. I came into Boston, this morning in the Stage from Quincy. General Jackson called upon me, and urged me to allow him further time for the payment of Swan’s Note which he has endorsed, and which is in suit at the Circuit Court, for the
Assignees of Robert Bird— He offers me by way of security lots of land in this town— Mr: Otis afterwards called upon me for the same purpose— I agreed to take the subject into Consideration— I wrote something this day, but not so much as I should have done.

27. I was engaged part of this morning in some business with Mr: Cleland the broker, which I finally concluded— Attended the meeting of the Academy; where there was little business done except making choice of the Officers— Dined at Judge Davis’s—My father—Dr: Tufts—President Webber, Dr: Waterhouse, Mr: Hedge—Mr: Bigelow, Mr: Lowell, and Judge Dawes, and Dr: Dexter were there— My father returned this Evening to Quincy— I spent it at Mr: Otis’s— Wrote scarcely a line this day.

28. I find that the only resource left me for accomplishing the task of writing which is made indispensable to me, is to commence with it in the morning, and resolve to do that, if every other of my usual occupations must be omitted. I have accordingly begun upon that plan this morning, and in consequence of it, wrote almost the whole of the daily portion I have assigned for myself— This was the day of the annual Election— The Legislature of the Commonwealth met; and the political Revolution is accomplished in both branches— A majority of whom are now of the democratic party— I went with Mr: Lowell and looked over the two houses which he proposes to sell to-morrow— I nearly concluded to take them at his price— In the afternoon I called on Mr: Gardner, and we attended for a few minutes on both branches of the General-Court— The Senate are so nearly divided between the two parties that they have not been able this day to chuse a President— Mr: Bacon and Mr: Otis are the Candidates—the former of whom will eventually carry the election— I called this day at the Office of the Register of Deeds, and examined Mr: Jackson’s Titles to the Lands he offers me as security— I also employed the Register to examine further.

29. I concluded this morning to take Mr: Lowell’s houses, at the terms which he proposed, and gave him notice of it. I also saw Mr: A. Dexter, and gave him the papers I had drawn up respecting the conveyance of my house to him— But Calling at the Office of the Register of Deeds, I found upon examination some records there which raised scruples in my mind as to the former of these transactions— I also found some conveyances of Genl: Jackson, which made a further explanation from him important— Saw Mr: H. G. Otis a short time on the subject, but not long enough to come to any settlement— The weather being very warm I spent the afternoon and Evening in my chamber.

30. Spent all the morning at home in writing— At one I went out, and met Mr: Lowell, with whom I had some conversation respecting the title, to his Estate, which I have agreed to purchase— I am to see him further concerning it— Saw Dr: Waterhouse, and partly engaged to take a chamber at his House for the Summer— This afternoon I attended at the Anniversary Address of the Charitable Fire Society, which was delivered by Mr: J. Phillips— Afterwards went and pass’d an hour with many of the members at Mr: A. Welles’s— He is the President of the Society. After a walk in the Mall I spent the remainder of the Evening at my chamber.

31. I intended to have gone out to Quincy this afternoon in the Stage, but miss’d of the opportunity by not properly bespeaking a seat— Dined with Mr: William Smith— Afternoon and Evening principally at my own chamber—
Day. Unsettled and irregular.
